articles.headline: Microsoft Produces a Winner in Tablets
articles.snippet: The company tries again with the Surface, and this time gets it right.
articles.abstract: The company tries again with the Surface, and this time gets it right.
articles.lead_paragraph: I can’t be the only person who needs fewer gadgets in his life.

articles.headline: Mobile Payments Gain Traction Among India’s Poor
articles.snippet: India’s huge population, broad adoption of cellphones and low airtime rates could make it the world’s largest market for wireless money transfers.
articles.abstract: India’s huge population, broad adoption of cellphones and low airtime rates could make it the world’s largest market for wireless money transfers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — In a narrow room filled with acrid fumes in one of the world’s largest slums, Chinak Ramtheol earns about $4 a day tending machines that melt and slice plastic trash into pellets for recycling.

articles.headline: Home Buyers Are Scarce, So Renters Take Their Place
articles.snippet: A growing number of investors and home builders are turning new homes into rentals to fill in the blanks of unfinished subdivisions.
articles.abstract: A growing number of investors and home builders are turning new homes into rentals to fill in the blanks of unfinished subdivisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Homeownership was out of reach for Tishri Hyman, a single mother of two with a good job but less than stellar credit. But three years ago, she found the next best thing: a brand new house, complete with a fireplace, that she could rent.

articles.headline: $15 Wage in Fast Food Stirs Debate on Effects
articles.snippet: Repeated strikes against fast-food restaurants have called for a sharp minimum-wage increase, to $15 an hour, but the side effects of such a jump on prices and employment are unclear.
articles.abstract: Repeated strikes against fast-food restaurants have called for a sharp minimum-wage increase, to $15 an hour, but the side effects of such a jump on prices and employment are unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: As fast-food workers plan yet another round of one-day strikes on Thursday in cities around the country, labor leaders, economists and industry officials continue to debate the potential effects of raising wages at companies that often assert that such increases would raise consumer prices and shrink the work force.

articles.headline: Amsterdam Has a Deal for Alcoholics: Work Paid in Beer
articles.snippet: Under a government-funded program denounced by conservative politicians, the city of tolerance is giving alcoholics street-cleaning jobs and paying them partly in beer.
articles.abstract: Under a government-funded program denounced by conservative politicians, the city of tolerance is giving alcoholics street-cleaning jobs and paying them partly in beer.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — After more than a decade out of work because of a back injury and chronic alcoholism, Fred Schiphorst finally landed a job last year and is determined to keep it. He gets up at 5:30 a.m., walks his dog and then puts on a red tie, ready to clean litter from the streets of eastern Amsterdam.

articles.headline: Chicago Pursues Deal to Change Pension Funding
articles.snippet: If no pension deal can be reached by November of next year, when the city will draft its next budget, Chicago will either have to raise taxes or cut services or some combination of both.
articles.abstract: If no pension deal can be reached by November of next year, when the city will draft its next budget, Chicago will either have to raise taxes or cut services or some combination of both.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. — First came the State of Illinois, now comes the City of Chicago.

articles.headline: Poor Black and Hispanic Men Are the Face of H.I.V.
articles.snippet: The number of new H.I.V. infections nationwide remains stubbornly stuck, with more and more occurring in young black and Hispanic men.
articles.abstract: The number of new H.I.V. infections nationwide remains stubbornly stuck, with more and more occurring in young black and Hispanic men.
articles.lead_paragraph: The AIDS epidemic in America is rapidly becoming concentrated among poor, young black and Hispanic men who have sex with men.

articles.headline: China Pressures U.S. Journalists, Prompting Warning From Biden
articles.snippet: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. raised the issue as Beijing withholds accreditation for journalists from The New York Times and Bloomberg.
articles.abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. raised the issue as Beijing withholds accreditation for journalists from The New York Times and Bloomberg.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China appears ready to force nearly two dozen journalists from American news organizations to leave the country by the end of the year, a significant increase in pressure on foreign news media that has prompted the American government’s first public warning about repercussions.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Large Companies Prepared to Pay Price on Carbon
articles.snippet: More than two dozen major American corporations are preparing to pay climate-related taxes, departing from conservative orthodoxy and exposing divisions between the Republican Party and its business supporters.
articles.abstract: More than two dozen major American corporations are preparing to pay climate-related taxes, departing from conservative orthodoxy and exposing divisions between the Republican Party and its business supporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than two dozen of the nation’s biggest corporations, including the five major oil companies, are planning their future growth on the expectation that the government will force them to pay a price for carbon pollution as a way to control global warming.

articles.headline: To Expand Reach, Retailers Take Aim at Hispanic Shoppers
articles.snippet: Macy’s will join media companies, political parties and other major retailers in showering attention on the country’s fast-growing Hispanic population.
articles.abstract: Macy’s will join media companies, political parties and other major retailers in showering attention on the country’s fast-growing Hispanic population.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few words used repeatedly start to sound like a chorus when Macy’s talks about unveiling its new line of clothing and accessories with Thalía Sodi, a Mexican pop star: Curves. Prints. Color.

articles.headline: Internet Firms Step Up Efforts to Stop Spying
articles.snippet: After surveillance by the National Security Agency, major Internet companies like Microsoft and Yahoo have moved to strengthen protections of users’ data.
articles.abstract: After surveillance by the National Security Agency, major Internet companies like Microsoft and Yahoo have moved to strengthen protections of users’ data.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Marissa Mayer, Yahoo’s chief executive, recently announced the company’s biggest security overhaul in more than a decade, she did not exactly receive a standing ovation.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Faster Pace of Growth May Not Last Long
articles.snippet: The estimate of growth in the third quarter was revised to a 3.6 percent rate from 2.8 percent, with much of the gain attributed to inventory changes and an improving trade picture.
articles.abstract: The estimate of growth in the third quarter was revised to a 3.6 percent rate from 2.8 percent, with much of the gain attributed to inventory changes and an improving trade picture.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stoked by rising inventories, the American economy grew at a significantly faster pace in the third quarter than first estimated, but probably at the expense of economic activity during the current quarter as businesses work off some of the excess stock on their shelves and in warehouses.
